title: Beginner’s Guide to Making an Infinite Water Source in Minecraft

steps.title: Dig a 1x3x1 or 2x2x1 hole.
steps.content: Dig a 1x3x1 or 2x2x1 hole. Click or use the left trigger button to mine dirt and grass blocks to dig a hole. The hole can either be a 1x3 rectangle or a 2x2 square, but either way, it should only be one block deep. [1] X Research source Materials needed: Shovel (optional). You don’t need any tools for this, but it’s faster if you use a shovel . You can make the hole bigger if you want, but it will take more water to fill. Once the hole is filled with water, the water you take from it will always be replenished.

steps.title: Place water into the outside two blocks if you made a 1x3 hole.
steps.content: Place water into the outside two blocks if you made a 1x3 hole. Equip a bucket of water, then click one of the outside blocks to place a water source block. Then, place another water block on the opposite end of the hole. The water will fill the center block. When the water is level with no visible flow in any direction, you’re finished. [2] X Research source Materials needed: Two buckets of water. If you’re not sure how to get this, check out our sections on crafting a bucket and obtaining water source blocks .

steps.title: Place water into diagonal corners if you made a 2x2 hole.
steps.content: Place water into diagonal corners if you made a 2x2 hole. Equip a bucket of water, then place the water into any block in your hole. Place a second block of water in the corner that’s diagonally opposite from the first one. The water will level out and have no visible flow. [3] X Research source Materials needed: Two buckets of water. If you want to make a bigger area of water, place your water source blocks in every other block, like a checkerboard pattern. [4] X Research source If the area is enclosed, alternating blocks around two sides of the perimeter may make the entire water layer into an infinite source—if that happens, the surface of the pool will become still. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Harvest the water and watch it refill.
steps.content: Harvest the water and watch it refill. Once your infinite water source is finished, you can take as much water as you want—it will automatically replenish itself every time you fill your bucket. Important note: If you made a 1x3 hole, only harvest water from the center block. If you pull water from the two outside edges, it will mess up the generator. [6] X Research source If you made a 2x2 hole, you can harvest water from any block and it will refill. Sometimes if you harvest water too quickly it will break the generator and you’ll have to replace the water source blocks. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Locate a body of water.
steps.content: Locate a body of water. It can be any river, lake, or ocean. Minecraft worlds are generated randomly, so you'll need to search the world to find a water source. Luckily, water is pretty common in Minecraft, and you shouldn't have to travel too far. Just make sure you find a solid water source—you can’t fill a bucket with flowing water. [8] X Research source You can also place a cauldron on the ground and wait for it to fill up with rain, then pour that into the bucket. A water source block will be still—it won’t have a flow. You can find it in water tanks, reservoirs, and puddles. Flowing water has a current, like a running stream or river.

steps.title: Fill a bucket with water.
steps.content: Fill a bucket with water. Once you find a water source block, place the bucket in your toolbar and select it. Stand next to a water source block and right-click or press the left trigger on a block of water. The image of the bucket in your inventory will be filled with water. [9] X Research source You’ll need at least two buckets of water to make an infinite water supply, but you can duplicate a water source block if you’re in an area where water is scarce, like the desert.

steps.title: Dig a hole 2 blocks deep and place water in the top hole.
steps.content: Dig a hole 2 blocks deep and place water in the top hole. Dig 2 blocks down into the dirt or grass. Equip your water bucket, then place the water into the top block in the hole (leaving the bottom block empty). [10] X Research source The water will run down into the hole, creating two water blocks, but the bottom block will be flowing water—not a water source block.

steps.title: Place bone meal in the bottom block to make kelp.
steps.content: Place bone meal in the bottom block to make kelp. Equip bone meal from your inventory. Click or press the left trigger button to place the bone meal into the bottom water block. The bone meal will transform into kelp, which will then trigger the water to become a water source block. [11] X Research source If you need to, you can dig a second hole beside the first one to better see into the bottom block, but you can place the bone meal while standing on the ground.

steps.title: Put the water into a bucket to harvest it.
steps.content: Put the water into a bucket to harvest it. Click to destroy the kelp, then equip a bucket and click to add the water to the bucket. If you have two buckets, you can pick up both water blocks at once. Otherwise, use the first block of water to empty the bucket, then come back and pick up the other one. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Smelt iron bars.
steps.content: Smelt iron bars. Iron bars are needed to craft buckets. To get iron, you must first mine iron ore from deep within a cave. You then need to locate or craft a furnace and use the furnace to smelt iron ore into iron bars. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Craft a bucket in a crafting table.
steps.content: Craft a bucket in a crafting table. Have at least three iron bars in your inventory, then open a crafting table by right-clicking on it or pressing the left trigger button. Select the bucket from the tab with the bucket and apple icon (Java Edition), or the tab with the bed and bucket icon (Bedrock Edition), or the Weapons and Tools tab (PlayStation Edition). Drag the bucket into your inventory. [14] X Research source If you have enough iron bars, you can craft multiple buckets to save yourself trips to the water source.

steps.title: How do you make flowing water still in Minecraft?
steps.content: How do you make flowing water still in Minecraft? To turn flowing water into a still water source block, trap it between two water source blocks. The easiest way to do that is to dig a 1x3 or 2x2 hole and place water source blocks on the outside or corner blocks.

steps.title: Do infinite water sources still work in Minecraft?
steps.content: Do infinite water sources still work in Minecraft? Yes, you can currently make an infinite water source in Minecraft Java and Bedrock using the approach described above.

steps.title: How do you get rid of an infinite water source in Minecraft?
steps.content: How do you get rid of an infinite water source in Minecraft? To get rid of an infinite water source, replace the block with another block. If you put lava on a water source block, it will either become obsidian (if you’re using a lava source block) or smooth stone if you’re using a flowing lava block). [15] X Research source
